sub_topic: The self-similarity of the Sierpinski carpet.
message_1:
What is the total number of squares in the nth iteration of the Sierpinski carpet, if the initial iteration has only one square (of side length 1)? 

For example, in the first iteration there is only one square, in the second iteration there are 8 squares (the original square and 7 smaller squares), and in the third iteration there are 64 squares (the original square and 63 smaller squares).
message_2:
The total number of squares in the nth iteration of the Sierpinski carpet can be found using the formula:

Total squares = (3^(n-1))^2

For example:

1st iteration: (3^(1-1))^2 = (3^0)^2 = 1^2 = 1 square
2nd iteration: (3^(2-1))^2 = (3^1)^2 = 3^2 = 9 squares (1 original square + 8 smaller squares)
3rd iteration: (3^(3-1))^2 = (3^2)^2 = 9^2 = 81 squares (1 original square + 80 smaller squares)

So, in the nth iteration, there will be (3^(n-1))^2 squares in the Sierpinski carpet.
